context: 'Servus' is the classic friendly Bavarian greeting. 'Grüß Gott' is more formal.

Always polite to ask in German first.
Use in emergencies.
In Germany, you usually pay at the table.

de: Ein Helles, bitte / Eine Maß, bitte
context: In Munich, 'Bier' usually means 'Helles' (Lager). A 'Maß' is a 1-liter glass.
Munich has great veg options, but traditional places use lots of bacon (Speck).
If you just ask for water, you will get sparkling (Sprudel) by default.
Look for signs marked 'Hbf' (Hauptbahnhof - Central Station).
Useful for checking S-Bahn directions.
Cash is still king in many small Munich shops!
Everyday greeting; use 'Guten Morgen' before ~ midday.
Use 'Guten Abend' in the evening; 'Gute Nacht' when leaving for bed.
Also means 'you're welcome' depending on context.
Polite and universally useful; 'Danke schön' is slightly more formal.
Useful to get someone's attention or apologize for bumping.
Basic intro.
Say this up front; many people will then try English.
Formal phrasing; in casual situations you can say 'Sprichst du Englisch?' to younger people.

en: How do I get to the main train station (Hauptbahnhof)?
context: Ask for directions to Munich Hauptbahnhof (central station).

en: Where is the U-Bahn / S-Bahn / tram stop?
es: ¿Dónde está la parada de metro (U-Bahn) / tren de cercanías (S-Bahn) / tranvía?
de: Wo ist die U-Bahn / S-Bahn / Tram-Haltestelle?
context: Useful when navigating public transport.

en: Which ticket do I need? / Where do I buy a ticket?
de: Welches Ticket brauche ich? / Wo kann ich ein Ticket kaufen?
context: MVV has zones and different day/strip tickets — ask staff if unsure. Tickets must be validated (entwertet) before travel. :contentReference[oaicite:5]{index=5}

en: Do I need to validate (stamp) my ticket?
context: In many MVV cases, single/strip/day tickets must be stamped at machines before boarding. :contentReference[oaicite:6]{index=6}

en: How long does it take to walk there?
de: Wie lange braucht man zu Fuß dorthin?
context: Good for estimating walking times.

en: Is this the right platform for the train to ... ?
es: ¿Es este el andén correcto para el tren a ... ?
de: Ist das der richtige Bahnsteig für den Zug nach ... ?
context: Ask before boarding—platforms can change.

en: I have a reservation under the name ...
es: Tengo una reserva a nombre de ...
de: Ich habe eine Reservierung auf den Namen ...
context: At hotel reception or guesthouse.
Ask about network name ('Netzwerkname') and password ('Passwort').

es: ¿A qué hora es el check-in / check-out?
context: Practical for planning arrival/departure.

en: Can I store my luggage here after check-out?
es: ¿Puedo dejar mi equipaje aquí después del check-out?
de: Kann ich nach dem Check-out mein Gepäck hier aufbewahren?
context: Many hotels offer luggage storage.

es: Una mesa para dos, por favor
context: Basic restaurant request.

en: Can I see the menu, please?
de: Kann ich bitte die Speisekarte sehen?
context: Ask for the menu if it isn't offered.

en: Do you have vegetarian / vegan options?
context: Useful — many places now offer options.

en: I'm allergic to ... (e.g. nuts, gluten, dairy)
es: Soy alérgico a ... (por ejemplo: frutos secos, gluten, lácteos)
de: Ich bin allergisch gegen ... (z. B. Nüsse, Gluten, Milchprodukte)
context: Be explicit — follow by 'Ist das im Gericht?' (Is that in the dish?).

en: Could I get the bill, please?
context: Say this when ready to pay. In Germany you normally tell the server the amount to pay when handing cash.
Not all small places accept cards — carry cash. :contentReference[oaicite:7]{index=7}
Common way to tip when paying in cash; you state the rounded total when handing over money.
Basic shopping question.

en: Do you have this in a different size / color?
de: Haben Sie das in einer anderen Größe / Farbe?
context: Useful in clothes shops.

en: Can I return this if it doesn't fit?
es: ¿Puedo devolver esto si no me queda bien?
de: Kann ich das zurückgeben, wenn es nicht passt?
context: Check store return policy.

en: Do you offer VAT refund (Tax free)?
context: Ask in bigger stores if you're non-EU and spending enough for tax-free shopping.

es: ¿Dónde está el cajero automático más cercano?
context: Carry cards and a little cash; watch ATM fees.

en: Can I pay by contactless / Apple Pay?
de: Kann ich kontaktlos / mit Apple Pay bezahlen?
context: Increasingly supported but check before ordering.

en: Call an ambulance! / I need a doctor!
de: Rufen Sie einen Krankenwagen! / Ich brauche einen Arzt!
context: In life-threatening emergencies dial 112 in Germany. :contentReference[oaicite:8]{index=8}
Head to police (110) to report a lost/stolen passport. :contentReference[oaicite:9]{index=9}
If it's outside hours, ask for the 'Notdienst' (emergency pharmacy). :contentReference[oaicite:10]{index=10}

en: I need medicine for ... (fever, stomach, allergy)
de: Ich brauche Medikamente gegen ... (Fieber, Magen, Allergie)
context: Ask the pharmacist; prescriptions asked for certain drugs.

en: Can you take me to this address, please?
es: ¿Puede llevarme a esta dirección, por favor?
de: Können Sie mich bitte zu dieser Adresse bringen?
context: Have the address written or on your phone to show the driver.

en: How much will that cost approximately?
de: Wie viel wird das ungefähr kosten?
context: Good to ask for an estimate before starting the taxi.
Useful when you don't have a phone handy.
Basic time words for planning.
Handy for schedules and opening hours.
General help request — people usually respond positively.
Use with map or address to ask directions.

en: Where can I buy a prepaid SIM card?
es: ¿Dónde puedo comprar una tarjeta SIM prepago?
de: Wo kann ich eine Prepaid-SIM kaufen?
context: Many phone shops and supermarkets sell SIMs; have your passport for registration if required.
Useful for postcards, parcels and stamps.
Formal phrasing for meeting someone.

en: Could I ask you a quick question?
de: Darf ich Ihnen kurz eine Frage stellen?
context: Polite opener for strangers.
Smoking rules vary — many indoor public places are non-smoking.
Repeat — many Bavarian dishes are meat heavy; ask for veggie.
Short words that appear on signs.
Signs often show 'WC' or 'Toilette'.

en: Could you write that down, please?
context: Helpful if pronunciation is hard — show the written text to locals.

en: Thank you very much / That was very helpful
es: Muchas gracias / Eso fue muy útil
de: Vielen Dank / Das war sehr hilfreich
context: Polite closing that leaves a good impression.
Polite and non-intrusive way to start a conversation in a bar or café.

en: Can I buy you a drink?
de: Darf ich dir ein Getränk ausgeben?
context: Common and acceptable, especially in bars or Biergärten.
A sincere compliment; Munich locals appreciate authenticity.
Useful in clubs, fest tents, or live-music settings.

en: Are you here alone or with friends?
de: Bist du alleine hier oder mit Freunden?
context: Shows interest while respecting social boundaries.

en: May I have your phone number?
context: Direct but acceptable; Germans appreciate straightforwardness.

en: Would you like to go for a walk with me?
de: Möchtest du mit mir spazieren gehen?
context: A classic Munich-friendly date idea; rivers and parks are popular.

en: Would you like to meet again?
es: ¿Te gustaría que nos viéramos otra vez?
de: Möchtest du dich wieder mit mir treffen?
context: Polite, non-pressuring way to propose a second meeting.

en: I really enjoyed talking with you.
de: Ich habe das Gespräch mit dir sehr genossen.
context: Warm, respectful way to close an encounter.
Useful when something awkward happens or communication breaks.

es: Por favor, para, no estoy interesado/a.
de: Bitte hör auf, ich bin nicht interessiert.
context: Clear communication—Germans respect direct statements.

en: I would like to go home now.
es: Me gustaría irme a casa ahora.
de: Ich möchte jetzt nach Hause gehen.
context: Useful when you want to end an interaction politely.

en: Do you know where the taxi stand is?
es: ¿Sabes dónde está la parada de taxis?
de: Weißt du, wo der Taxistand ist?
context: Useful late at night after bars or clubs.
Essential in uncomfortable or unsafe situations.
